On 11/8/06, Peter DePasquale <peter.depasquale@...> wrote:
>
> * Am I correct in assuming that due to the presence of either JUnit or
> ANT,
> the System.in stream is misdirected or overridden and thus standard input
> techniques can not be used?  (History: I can't get a decent ANT java task
> to
> run the program cleanly either since there seem to be issues with the
> buffering of the input prompts ( System.out.println calls).



There may be a way to do it, but the advantages of using JUnit for this
particular test, rather than a quick main() method are slim.  However, see
below.


* Is it even possible to create a JUnit test on a text-based application
> which requires user input?  I see no examples of this type of activity in
> the JUnit documentation...



Absolutely.  I've done it several times.  The key is to make sure that
rather than directly reading from System.in everywhere that you want input,
you make the input stream (and probably output stream) parameters to your
class or method.  Then, in your JUnit test, you can use ByteArrayInputStream
to queue up "fake" input.


* The dashes following the hostname are not part of my output.  Where did
> they come from?



I think they are from ant, marking the end of standard output.


* Why will the program execute but not wait for user input.  It does this
> without fail when the program is run from the command line.



Which behavior is "this" in the last sentence?

Good luck,

   David Saff
